div1.p: CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT
Sessions Paper.
MOORE, MAYOR.
SECOND SESSION, HELD DECEMBER 12TH, 1898.
MINUTES OF EVIDENCE,
TAKEN IN SHORT-HAND BY
JAMES DROVER BARNETT
AND
ALEXANDER BUCKLER,
Short-hand Writers to the Court,
ROLLS CHAMBERS, No. 89, CHANCERY LANE.
THE POINTS OF LAW AND PRACTICE
REVISED AND EDITED BY
EDWARD T. E. BESLEY, ESQ., Q.C.,
OF THE MIDDLE TEMPLE, BARRISTER-AT-LAW.
LONDON:
STEVENS AND SONS, LIMITED, 119, CHANCERY LANE,
Law Booksellers and Publishers.
THE
WHOLE PROCEEDINGS
On the Queen's Commission of
OYER AND TERMINER AND GAOL DELIVERY
FOR
The City of London,
AND GAOL DELIVERY FOR THE
COUNTY OF MIDDLESEX AND THE PARTS OF THE COUNTIES OF ESSEX. KENT, AND SURREY WITHIN THE JURISDICTION
OF THE
CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT,
INCLUDING CASES COMMITTED TO THIS COURT UNDER ORDER IN
COUNCIL, PURSUANT TO WINTER ASSIZE ACTS OF 1879.
Held on Monday, December 12th, 1898, and following days,

BEFORE THE RIGHT HON. SIR JOHN VOCE MOORE, LORD MAYOR of the City of London; the Hon. Sir
HENRY HAWKINS , Knt., and the Hon. Sir
ALFRED WILLS , Knt., two of the Justices of the High Court; Sir
REGINALD HANSON , Bart., M.P., and Sir
DAVID EVANS , K.C.M.G., Alder
men of the said City; Sir
CHARLES HALL , K.C.M.G., Q.C., M.P., Recorder of the said City;
ALFRED JAMES NEWTON , Esq., Sir JOSEPH COCKFIELD DIMSDALE, Knt.,
MARCUS SAMUEL , Esq.,
JOHN POUND Esq.,
WALTER VAUGHAN MORGAN , Esq.,
HENRY GEORGE SMALLMAN , Esq., and
JOHN KNILL , Esq., other of the Aldermen of the said City; and Sir FORREST FULTON, Knc., Q.C., Common Serjeant of the said City; Her Majesty's Justices of Oyer and Terminer and General Gaol Delivery, holden for the said City, and Judges of the Central Criminal Court.
FREDERICK PRAT ALLISTON . Esq., Alderman.

Lieut.-Col.
CLIFFORD PROBYN , J.P., L.C.C.
LEONARD JAMES MATON , Esq.
CLARENCE RICHARD HALSK, Esq.
CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT.
MOORE, MAYOR. SECOND SESSION,

A star (*) denotes that prisoners have been previously in custodyâ€”two stars (**) that they have been more than once in custodyâ€”a dagger (â€ ) that they are known to be the associates of bad charactersâ€”the figures after the name in the indictment denote the prisoner's age.
LONDON AND MIDDLESEX CASES.

65.
JOHN WESTON (25), and
HANNAH HARRISS (30)
, stealing a basket and other articles from the
Civil Service Supply Association.
MR. THOMPSON, for the prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

66.
WILLIAM HAMMOND (28)
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing the sum of Â£835 11s. 10d., the moneys of
Theodore Furst, his master.â€”
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.

67.
FREDERICK JAMES NICHOLSON (22)
, to stealing two post letters the property of
the Postmaster-General, he being employed under the Post Officeâ€”
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

68.
JOSEPH BUTCHER (40)
, to stealing a post letter and two postal orders the property of
the Postmaster General, he being employed under the Post Office.â€”
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
Twelve Month's Hard Labour. And

69.
WILLIAM FLEMING (22)
, to breaking and entering a warehouse and stealing There from a quantity of screws and other articles, the property of
Frederick Perman Matthews.â€”
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

70.
CHARLES RAWLINGS (20)
, robbery with violence on
Edward Swift and stealing a railway ticket and Â£12 10s, his property.

EDWARD SWIFT . I am a discharged soldier, of 13, Greenwood Street, Leedsâ€”I was invalided home from Singaporeâ€”on December 2nd, about 9.30, I was coming out of the Metropolitan Railway Station in Gray's Inn Road when the prisoner came up to me and asked me if I had been a soldier; I said "Yes"â€”he asked me if I would treat him; I said "No"; and he struck me across the eye and he gave me a kick; I fell down, about five of his companions came round and one of them took Â£12 10s. out of my pocket and then ran awayâ€”I went to see if I could see any of themâ€”I saw the prisoner and gave him into custodyâ€”I did not see where the others came fromâ€”I had never seen the prisoner beforeâ€”I was sober.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I was not talking to two womenâ€”the
others ran away and left meâ€”you gave me a kick on the ground and then ranâ€”I followed you and gave you in charge.

ROBERT HOLDING (43 E). On December 2nd I was on fixed point duty at the corner of Euston Roadâ€”the last witness came and made a complaint to me about 10.45 p.m.â€”he pointed out the prisoner tome, who was standing at the corner of York Road and Euston Roadâ€”I went towards the prisoner and he ran away towards Pentonville Roadâ€”I saw him again in Gray's Inn Road; he bad two women with himâ€”I then lost sight of himâ€”I saw him again and I got on a 'bus and when opposite him I jumped off and took him into custodyâ€”I told him what he was charged withâ€”he said "I own I had a fight with him but I never took anything from him"â€”I took him to the stationâ€”he made no reply to the chargeâ€”I searched himâ€”nothing was found on him.

CHARLES RAWLINGS (The prisoner) sworn. On December 2nd I was in York Road and I saw the prosecutor paying two young women. I said "Why do you pay two women? can't you pay a man?"â€”He said "Yes, I can hit you"â€”he took his coat off and he hit me, I hit him and knocked him down, he then said somebody had robbed himâ€”I was by myself then.

Cross-examined. I was not doing anything in Gray's Inn Roadâ€”I was out of workâ€”I did not see any scuffle with anybody elseâ€”nobody touched him but meâ€”two women asked him if he wanted any flowers and he was hitting them.
EDWARD SWIFT (Re-examined). I never spoke to a woman at all.

GUILTY .â€” He was stated to be an associate of thieves and teas a deserter from the Army.â€”
Eight Months' Hard Labour
and Twenty Strokes with the Cat.

71.
FREDERICK BURDISS (26)
PLEADED GUILTY
to burglary in the house of
the Watchmakers' Alliance Company and stealing thirty-nine watches, their property.â€”Having been convicted of felony on July 20th, 1896. Six other convictions were proved against him.

72.
ROBINS PURDY (54)
, for a defamatory libel on
Williams, Terry, and Field, Limited, with intent to extort money, to which he
PLEADED NOT GUILTY, and a justification.

p.hi: informed the Prisoner that the justification was bad in law, but he persisted in being tried.

div1.p:
ALFRED SHOVER WILLIAMS . I am a director of Williams, Terry, and Field, of 108, Fenchurch-street, sole managers in London of the Atlantic Transport Company, Limitedâ€”we are registered as the managing owners of the steamship Mohegan, which was lately wrecked off the Cornish coastâ€”on October 31st we received this letter, marked "A," by post in an open envelope, with a halfpenny stamp on it, and on Novem
ber 2nd we received a letter in the same form from Lloyd's, and another

from the Gaiety Theatre, which they sent on to usâ€”on November 8th we received from Cook and Son, the tourist agents, this postcard, in which we are also described as the ownersâ€”in two of those documents I am described as a ship's captain, who had his certificate suspendedâ€”I am not a ship's captain, and never was, and I know nothing of the prisonerâ€”we have at the Docks a list of men who are un
desirable men, who are not fit to be employed; I have inquired, and the prisoner's name is not on the listâ€”I never heard of his nameâ€”the list does not apply to ships' captains at all.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. We had a Captain Williams in our employment up to seven years agoâ€”he was no relative of mineâ€”you never asked me for any money.

HENRY GEORGE WRIGHT . I am clerk to Pritchard and Sons, solicitors, of Gracechurch Streetâ€”on November 1st, having all these letters placed in my hands, I went to Caulfield Road, East Ham, and met the prisoner outsideâ€”I told him I was looking for Norfolk Houseâ€”he said that he knew Captain Purdy, and took me to Norfolk Houseâ€”he then said, "I am Captain Purdy"â€”he took me into a sitting-room, outside the door of which a paper was pinned up marked "The Norfolk Steamship Company"â€”I told him that I came to ascertain particulars respecting the loss of the Mohegan, and that I was a friend of one of the chief officers who was drownedâ€”he asked me to accept one of his pamphlets, and handed me this one (produced)â€”it is not printed; they are all writtenâ€”he told me that Captain Williams, the head of the firm, had "put the Suffolk away," and had his certificate suspended for six months; that the firm was Williams, Terry and Co., and that they were a bet of liars, rogues, and thieves, and that they had had Â£100 from the underwritersâ€”he said, "They have black-listed me, and I will black-list them unless they make it worth my while"â€”he showed me a letter from the late Captain Griffiths, captain of the Moheganâ€”I asked him to give it to meâ€”he said, "No; I cannot give it to you; but I will make you a copy of it"â€”he started to copy it, and I finished itâ€”this is it; it is dated March 25th, 1898, from Captain Griffiths to Purdyâ€”(The COURT refund to allow this letter to be read.)â€”hesaid that he had sent the letters to Lloyd's, and had distributed them all round the Docks, and also to the brokers who had insured the Moheganâ€”Isaid, "Don't you think you have acted very foolishly; you will get yourself into trouble?"â€”he then flew into a passionâ€”I heard bounds in the next room, which was only separated by folding doorsâ€”he screamed, a man smoking a cigarette came who was very violent, and I made for the door.
Cross-examined. I asked you for lettersâ€”I did not call you a fool; I told you you were very sillyâ€”I may he said that you were very foolish.
The Prisoner's statement before the Magistrate;"I did write the letters, believing them to be the truth. I said I believed the shipowner's clerk had black-listed me, but I did not ask for any money."

JAMKS SCOTT (Called by the COURT). I am medical officer, of Holloway Prisonâ€”the prisoner has been confined there about a monthâ€”I have kept him under special observation since last Session in consequence of the directions of the Court, and have conversed with him daily for a quarter of an hour or so at a timeâ€”I think he is of weak mind and takes

exaggerated and distorted views of nautical mattersâ€”I can scarcely call them insane delusionsâ€”I can not sign a certificate that he is insaneâ€”I conversed with him about the loss of this steamshipâ€”he had a great deal to say about her being scuttledâ€”he said that the captain's certificate had been suspended and the ship had been wilfully wreckedâ€”he seemed to think that he had a mission to put before the public.

NOT GUILTY of the attempt to extort money. GUILTY of libel, but the Jury considered that he was not responsible for his actions. He promised to cease from circulating the pamphlets.
To enter into his own recognisances to come up for judgment if called upon.

73.
ALFRED JOHN CHURCHER and
ALFRED MILLER
, unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

MILLER
PLEADED GUILTY .

REIALI ANGELO (Interpreted). I am a dealer in ice cream, at 40, Hackney Roadâ€”on November 17th at 6 o'clock Churcher came in and asked me if I had change for a half-crownâ€”I gave him two shillings and a sixpenceâ€”I examined his half-crown and said in English, "It is no good, this half-crown"â€”as soon as he saw me move he began to run, and I followedâ€”I afterwards saw him with a policeman, to whom I handed the coin.

ARTHUR FROST (252 J). On November 17th, shortly after 6 p.m., I was on duty in Hackney Road, and saw the prisoner followed by several peopleâ€”I stopped himâ€”he said, "I have done nothing"â€”the prosecutor came up with a half-crown, and said, "It is bad," pointing to the prisoner, who said, "This is a bad job for me that I should be put away like this, worse luck; a chap named Miller gave it to me; I did not know it was a bad one"â€”he did not say why he ran awayâ€”I took him to the stationâ€”he made no reply to the chargeâ€”I found on him 2s. 6d. in silver and 4d.â€”I afterwards went to 449, Hackney Road, and took Miller.
WILLIAM JOHN WKBSTER . I am Inspector of coin to Her Majesty's Mintâ€”this half crown is counterfeit.

CHURCHERâ€”
GUILTY.â€”Recommended to mercy by the JURY, and his master engaged to take him back.â€”
Discharged on recognisances.

MILLERâ€”
fourteen Days' Hard Labour.

74.
CHARLES WILLIAMS (20),
PLEADED GUILTY
to wilful and corrupt perjury, committed on a bastardy summons.
To enter into recognisances.

75.
MARTHA AMELIA HOWE (34)
PLEADED GUILTY
to causing a false entry to be made in a certain death register;
also to wilful and corrupt perjury
Two previous convictions were proved against her.â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

76.
HENRY SPARKS (35)
, to indecently assaulting
Amelia Hill. He received a good character.â€”
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
Judgment respited.

77.
ALGERNON CROOME
, to unlawfully obtaining goods on credit within four months of his bankruptcyâ€”
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
To enter into his own recognis
ances. And

78.
JAMES GEORGE BSCOTT (29)
, to forging and uttering a receipt for 6s. 8d., with intent to defraud.â€”
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
Judgment respited.

79.
GEORGE PAGE (38)
, Embezzling 10s.,Â£1 11s., and 3s. 6d., the moneys of
Norris Robert Such, his master.

MAURICE ROBERT SAXE . I trade as the Patent Window Cleaning Company, 132, City Roadâ€”the prisoner was my traveller to solicit ordersâ€”the mode of payment was that he was to receive the first month's money on every contract for twelve months, besides out-of-pocket expenses, and if the contract was for six months he would only get halfâ€”it was not his duty to collect the money, I had warned him about thatâ€”I had a special collector, Mr. Jollyâ€”the prisoner never returned after Novem
ber 3rdâ€”I had not given him authority to collect moneyâ€”my collector gave me information, and I applied to the policeâ€”Mr. Coldry owed me the first month's money, 10s.â€”the prisoner had obtained him as a customer, and I have paid him his commission for thatâ€”Mr. Winsor owed me Â£1 11s.â€”the collector told me somethingâ€”I did not owe the prisoner Â£4 at the time he was arrested; he was indebted to us irrespective of these sums.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I found you very dishonest, during the last four monthsâ€”you forged Mr. Smith's name to a contract for twelve months, and I can put that contract inâ€”you owe me 13s. 3d. besides what you have takenâ€”I did not delay paymentsâ€”you got 5s. from Mr. Reynolds, of Wood Green, and insulted him and he stopped the contractâ€”money was not paid to me without receiptsâ€”I never went into partners ship with youâ€”this memorandum (Produced by the prisoner) is written by youâ€”this is the agreement with the School Boardâ€”your name does not appear upon itâ€”you have taken Â£1 11s. in that case.

JOHN WINSOR . I am caretaker at Blackstock Road Board Schoolâ€”I entered into a contract with this company to have the windows cleanedâ€”it was not the prisoner who got me to sign this contractâ€”on November 10th Â£1 11s. was due upon it, and the prisoner called on me and repre
sented himself as the collector, and said that he called for the moneyâ€”I complained about the workâ€”he said that it should be improvedâ€”I gave him Â£1 on account, thinking he was the collectorâ€”on November 14th he came again, and I gave him the balance, 11s.â€”he gave me this receipt. (This was signed "C. P." and was for Â£1 received on account, and 11s. balance.)â€”I gave him another verbal order to clean windows.
Cross-examined. I first saw you when I paid you the Â£1â€”your wife is not hereâ€”she has not been required to attendâ€”I told her that you wished her to come to the police-court.
By the COURT. He gave me a receipt for Â£1 and the 11s.â€”the original contract was for Â£1 12s. 6d. but 1s. 6d. was deducted because another man had that.

FRANCIS COLDRY . I live at Crouch Endâ€”I had a contract with this window-cleaning company first on October 6th for one monthâ€”on Novem
ber 4th the prisoner came to inquire whether the work was satisfactory
and whether I would renew the contract for twelve monthsâ€”10s. was due, which I paid him, and he gave me this receipt (produced)â€”I did not notice that he had not put my name upon it.
Cross-examined. I believe you made some remark about the money being due on the 6th, and I paid itâ€”it would be due on the Saturday.

CHARLES DOLDEN (Detective-Sergeant 7). I had a warrant for the prisoner's arrest, and on November 26th I went to his house and read the warrant to himâ€”he said, "I admit I had the money; it was only part of what he owes me; he now owes me Â£10."

GEORGE PAGE (The. prisoner, sworn.) The money was given to me voluntarilyâ€”the prosecutor neglected to pay me money due to me, and for several weeks they never paid me anythingâ€”I considered myself legally entitled to the money as a bailee for the amount he owed meâ€”he refused to give me any money for four weeks, except on account.

Cross-examined. I left on November 3rd; I went back several timesâ€”I went back on the Friday; I had received these moneys thenâ€”I told Mr. Saxe by letter of November 14th that I had received them, and 1 saw him and told him several timesâ€”I had collected 3s. 6d. from Mrs. Higging on November 3rd; I did not tell him thatâ€”I gave a receipt on one of the note-cards of the companyâ€”I went to Mr. Coldry on November 4th, and got 10s., but did not tell Mr. Saxe that I had not done so before the 14th.

Prisoner's Defence. I did not know when I was taking this money that I was doing anything wrong; they deprived me of money week after week, and I can refer them to the money that was due to me. I was told that I was indemnified against any action. I thought the counter claim would go against the other money, and I consider that I am much wronged. The provocation I have received from the prosecutor week after week and month after month is enough to drive any one to distraction.
GUILTY .

â€”He then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of larceny on Septem
ber 10th, 1894, and three other convictions were proved against him.

80.
GEORGE HACKSHAW (45)
unlawfully assaulting
Elizabeth Cunningham, and occasioning her actual bodily harm.

ELIZABETH CUNNINGHAM . On October 2nd I met the prisoner in Somers Townâ€”I am 23 years oldâ€”I told him I wanted to go to Batierseaâ€”he took me home with himâ€”I stayed there seven weeksâ€”on Friday night, November 26th, I came back to the houseâ€”he told me to go and I did go, and I got a situation the same day and he got me turned outâ€”I was not on daily service, I lived here; I went back to the prisoner's house to pay some money, and the lady asked me to stop there and I stopped the nightâ€”on the Saturday morning he heard me go outâ€”he said, "I am very sorry I got you turned out, I will keep you till you get work again," but he struck me the same day on my head, and knocked me in
sensible with a pokerâ€”first he bit me with the poker, and I took a poker and hit him back againâ€”this was at 4 30 p.m., but he hit me first at 12 o'clock.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You were not in bed at 12 o'clock, you were dressedâ€”you struck me with the tongs at 12 o'clock, and with the poker at 4 o'clockâ€”I did not shake you when you were in bed, and ask you to get up and give me a drink, I had money of my own.

JOHN BRTHEL (21 Y R). On November 26th shortly after 4 p.m. I was called to 31, Johnson Street, and found the prosecutrix in the front room, ground floor, bleeding from severe cuts on her headâ€”a surgeon was sent for, and the was sent to the hospitalâ€”I went back to Johnson Street, looked about the room, and found the tongs in the front room, and the poker in the bedroom which belongs to another womanâ€”the prisoner was in custody for being drunkâ€”I charged himâ€”he said nothing.

MARY ANN SAUNDERSON . I am attached to the Temperance Hospitalâ€”the prosecutrix was brought there suffering from seven scalp woundsâ€”a blunt instrument such as a poker or tongs would inflict themâ€”these fire-irons would do soâ€”they were serious wounds, very severe scalp woundsâ€”she had lost much blood.

MARY BROWN . I live at 31, Johnson Streetâ€”on November 26th I saw the prisoner at a little after 12 coining from the back parlour with the tongs in his hand following the prosecutrixâ€”an old lady lived in the back parlourâ€”he called the prosecutrix a foul name and struck herâ€”I had heard him say at 6 o'clock that morning that he would swing for her before longâ€”I saw him at 4 o'clock that afternoon with a poker in his hand and he said that he had done for her.

ANN JAY . I take care of No. 31, Johnson Streetâ€”on a Saturday a fortnight ago the prosecutrix came-out of the back parlour into my room for a shawlâ€”the prisoner ran after herâ€”I went to my room to take a baby which I nursed, out of the cradleâ€”I said, "George, you will kill her"â€”he said, "Yes and I will till you too," and struck me across my shoulders, a woman 75 years of ageâ€”he struck the prosecutrix seven or eight times, and each time made a wound.

A statement made by the prisoner at the station was here put in in which he said that he met the prosecutrix in Old Street, who stated that she was in great distress and he took her home to his landlady, stating that she was his cousin, and that he would pay for her keep, but afterwards told her to obtain another home; that on the day in question she knocked at his door at 6 40 a.m., and told him to look out for himself before the day was out; that she gave him two black eyes and five wounds, and that she had told him that she was an the street of Liverpool before she was sixteen years old.

ELIZABETH CUNNINGHAM (Re-examined). I was at Liverpool some timeâ€”I have been convicted no less than twenty-seven times of assaults on the. police, receiving stolen goods, shop breaking, and other offences, chiefly assaults, on each of which I have been sent to prison for various terms.
BENJAMIN NORMAN (Detective, G). I received a communication from Holloway yesterday morningâ€”I received thin list, stating that the prose cutrix has been convicted twenty-seven times.
GUILTY .â€”He handed in certificates of his previous good character.â€”Judgment respited.

81.
EDWARD HAMPSHIRE,
GEORGE RILEY , and
ERNEST HAWKINS
PLEADED GUILTY
to attempting to break into the shop of
Thomas Hexton, with intent to steal;
also to being found by night with
out lawful excuse in possession of implements of housebreaking. HAMPSHIRE and RILEYâ€”
Eight Months' Hard Labour.
HAWKINS*â€”
Nine Months Hard Labour.

82.
GEORGE EDWARD NOTLEY (57)
, to feloniously marrying
Louisa Richardson, his wife being alive.â€”
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
Two Days' Imprisonment.

83.
CADWALLADER TUDOR EDWARDS (36)
, conspiring with
Hastings Hugh Fraser and others, unknown, to defraud
James Smith Joyce of his moneys.
The prisoner stated, in the hearing of the JURY, that he was
GUILTY .

p.hi:
They found that veldt.â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

div1.p:
84.
ADAM BETHUME CLAPPERTON (27) and
BERT HOL
LOWAY (32)
, forging and uttering a bill of sale with intent to defraud.

CHARLES GRAHAM JOHNSTON . I live at 131, The Grove, Hammer
smithâ€”I have an agency for American firms in this countryâ€”previous to the autumn of 1897 I had been abroad for some years on business con
nected with the Bovril and other limited companiesâ€”I there attended various exhibitionsâ€”coming home in August last year I found that my niece had married the prisoner Clapperconâ€”at the end of that year I came from Scotlandâ€”I visited his house in December, and went to reside there at the end of Januaryâ€”in February at his request I advanced him money for his business as a money-lenderâ€”his agreement limited the amount to Â£200â€”that was invested in about nine weeksâ€”Clapperton conducted the details of the businessâ€”I also advanced other larger sums upon securities recommended by Clappertonâ€”in August this year he said there was a man in the Bengal Road who wanted Â£200, which I refused to advance at first, but on August 30th he produced this bill of saleâ€”he said it was genuine, and that I should have ample security for Â£200, and that the furniture represented the value mentioned in the bill of saleâ€”I accepted thatâ€”he also showed me this life policy of the Scottish Union Office for Â£250â€”he said it was all rightâ€”on August 30th he introduced another gentleman as Lemere, to whom, after some conversation on Clipperton's re
presentation, I gave this chequeâ€”I after wardspicked the prisoner Hollo way out as Lemereâ€”I wrote the name on the side of the chequeâ€”this is the counterfoil-J. M. Ellis was represented to be agent for Clapperton in the matter of Â£200, which was to be part of another transaction of Â£700 to purchase a "saloon" business or public-houseâ€”the cheque was endorsed and paid through the bankâ€”I do not know the person who endorsed itâ€”Clapperton said "We will have the bill of sale registered"â€”I after
wards

got this telegram at Soathend, saying it was duly registeredâ€”I also spoke to him in a general way, and he said it was all rightâ€”I did not hear any more till Clapperton and his clerk King said somebody was looking after me to get money out of meâ€”Clapper
ton said he had seen the man in his public-house, and that we would go and see himâ€”I asked him where it wasâ€”he said it was by Chancery Laneâ€”he proposed that I should lend him Â£500 on mortgage to a lady for a businessâ€”I made inquiries and refused to lend itâ€”after receiving this note, "Kindly meet meat Bishopsgate Station. Very important, to see solicitor re Lemere. Do not come out until you leave for the City.â€”ADAM, "I went with Clapperton to see Mr. Francis, a solicitor in the Cityâ€”he said the bill of sale was no good, and that we had better have his mouth shut upâ€”one gentleman present said that I had better take action against him for blackmail if he said anythingâ€”the upshot of the conversation was that I was to meet them on the Satur
day, and make an appointment with an inspector of police, but I was to keep the documents, and not give them up to anyoneâ€”when I saw some
thing was wrong I went to another solicitor, who advised me to go to the police at once, and I wont and got a warrantâ€”Clapperton rendered accounts supposed to be weekly, but they were fortnightly or monthlyâ€”this is one for four weeks ending September 12th, 1898â€”I got that about a fortnight after September 12thâ€”two of the items in this account are a payment from me of Â£200 on September 10th, and an advance to B. A. Lemere of Â£200â€”those balance each other.

Cross-examined. I have been brought up in the meat businessâ€”confined my attention to that in "Americaâ€”I was arranging to go to Australia this year in the same businessâ€”I have never been in businessâ€”I was employed as foreman and managerâ€”I have seen twenty years in the meat business generally-my arrangements to go to Australia were with Clappertonâ€”I expected a salary and commissionâ€”I expected Â£500â€”I preferred to stay here, but I did not suggest a partnership with Clapperton he carried out the transactions as to money-lending himself with three or four exceptionsâ€”I have heard of some of the names you mention but he carried out the details and I merely kept the promissory notes and papers as securities for what I advancedâ€”I do not remember anything about the transactionsâ€”I redeemed jewellery as a friendly transactionâ€”I did not instruct Clapperton to de
mand Â£17 10s.â€”Mrs. Dodridge's husband did not threaten me with proceedingsâ€”I did not accept a small sum in satisfactionâ€”I did not make such a statement at the Police-courtâ€”I did not receive any interest; I received a small sum, which Mrs. Dodridge insisted uponâ€”I think it was Â£12 8s.â€”her husband simply came to me to settle up the matterâ€”I did not authorise Clapperton, but he demanded Â£17 10â€”he made advances with my moneyâ€”I was not present when promissory notes were signed to the best of my recollectionâ€”I have no recollection of any woman signing her husband's name in my presence to promissory notesâ€”I was not aware he was lending to married womenâ€”nor that he threatened them with forgery for singing their names unless they paid a sum of moneyâ€”that never came to my knowledgeâ€”I objected in May last to the whole business of money-lendingâ€”I said so at the Police-courtâ€”Clapperton explained that a poor

baker wanted new ovens to increase his business, and I considered by lending him money I was doing him a benefitâ€”I had Â£250â€”I had no security but a life policy and a promissory note for Â£275, to be paid in quarterly instilmentsâ€”Â£25 was not the interest per month, but for the use of the moneyâ€”he was to pay Â£35 per quarterâ€”I did not press for paymentâ€”I did not force him to pay another Â£25â€”I did not tell Clapperton to press the borrowerâ€”Clapperton went to him of his own accordâ€”I did not discuss Miss Turner's loanâ€”Gale I know now was the man she was said to be going to marryâ€”the note was signed in both namesâ€”I know now that Sarah Ann Brown, of Hull, signed her husband's nameâ€”Clapperton kept back the fact when he handed the notes to meâ€”I knew Mr. Brown was a sailor, and probably at seaâ€”I understood he had given his consentâ€”in the six months I had about 130 notesâ€”Clapperton deducted his rent of 10s. a weekâ€”I never owed him any moneyâ€”I have his receiptsâ€”I did not hand him the cheque for Â£200 for his own expensesâ€”my suspicions were first aroused when I went to Mr. Francis's officesâ€”I took Clapperton to Mr. Monroe because there was a dispute about a picture, and I wanted to avoid a talkâ€”I put myself entirely in Clapper
ton's handsâ€”he was to pay me 5 per cent, on increase of businessâ€”in Lemere's case he said he would get Â£10 10s.â€”I took the pro
missory notes to be genuineâ€”I believed every transaction to be genuine I was not always in the office when transactions took placeâ€”I had not known Lemere previous to his transactionâ€”I did not know him to be the prisoner Hollowayâ€”Sandford was the office boyâ€”he never introduced Lemere as Holloway.

Re-examined. the Â£200 cheque has not been suggested to me as ex
penses before to-dayâ€”before the Magistrate the cheque was said to relate to Mortimerâ€”these letters are Clapperton's writing. (These were from A. Clapperton, Holloway Prison, and addressed to Mrs. Brown; one dated "24-11-93," stated that he was innocently drawn into a transaction with another party, and was on remand; that her documents had been received at his house; that he was giving up business, and his solicitors were calling in his accounts, but that he was desirous of settling direct, and asking Mrs. Brown to pay the bank receipt for Â£150, dated April 1st, in her name to his clerk, and he would allow her the Â£8 interest, and deduct Â£25 from her indebtedness of Â£225, thus giving her a rebate of Â£33, the remaining Â£50 to be paid by monthly instalments of Â£2 to the prisoner's wife, the clerk to deliver up receipts and policies; that Percy Hilton was only a trading name, and asking for a wire reply to Holloway Prison, as he did not want the lawyers to call her loan in, as they would write to Captain Brown Another letter, of" 1-12-98," acknowledged two letters and a telegram, regretting that he could not settle upon her terms, and stating that he enclosed bank receipts for Â£150 for Mrs. Brown to cash and remit to his clerk, asking for a wire that she had done so, or he would stop payment of the deposits, and through the bank communicate with "the Captain." Another letter from Holloway Prison, of "16-11-98," was to the witness's brother and complained of being prosecuted through attending to prosecutor's busi
ness of a money-lender at from 60 to 700 per cent.)â€”I dis
regnrded that letterâ€”on October 11th I received this letter from Clapperton (acknowledging a payment by a Mr. Appleton

of Â£12 10s. and two other payments, and that he had another letter from Hull giving the date of Captain Brown's arrival and stating, "I am not inclined to answer same at the present moment, as I intend taking advice in the matter. Your having instructed me to have Captain Brown's signature appended to the documents puts the matter in an awkward posi
tion" that he should atavist instructions, and stating "If Captain Brown hears of the circumstances he can redeem his bank deposit receipt and squash the contract")â€”I had never given him instructions for giving Captain Brown's name to be put upon the securities to my recollectionâ€”Clapperton had not capital of his own in a large senseâ€”his business was small before I provided the moneyâ€”this is Appleton's bill referred to in the letterâ€”I got this letter from Clapperton of October 15th (from 189, The Grove, Hammersmith, asking for accounts to be returned to enable him to make duplicates and for books)â€”returned the Repayment Book, and stated my willingness to give him copies of the accounts requiredâ€”on October 17th he sent me this letter (pressing for accountsâ€”I had seen him between October 26th and 27th, but do not think we said anything about Captain Brown's signatureâ€”I received this letter from him on October 26th (offering to cancel letter of 11th inst. for an advance Â£200 for two years and to return certain promissory notes and an advance of Â£30 at 15 per cent, to his clerk, King, and himself, trading as"The Grove Dental Company," and undertaking to collect and hand over moneys due less actual expenses)â€”I. believed Appleton's, Brandon's and Bay ley's bills (pro
duced) were genuine securities when I made the advance to Hiltonâ€”I am not aware that I owed Clapperton money in Septemberâ€”he rendered accounts and there would be a balance Very oftenâ€”the last account is up to October 31st, when I advanced him Â£100 upon his promissory note for loansâ€”I wished to relinquish the businessâ€”both the signatures to this bill of Turner and Gale is in the same writingâ€”I notice it now for the first time.

By MR. HUGHES The promissory notes came into my possession about the dates they bear a themâ€”I have no recollection of being present when Turner's was signedâ€”I may have been in the office when the money was lentâ€”the business was never mineâ€”this note is also signed by James and Amelia Collins in the same writingâ€”I believe the money was lent to the ladyâ€”my sight is slightly defectiveâ€”I never carried on a money lending businessâ€”I am the victimâ€”philanthropist if you likeâ€”I recollect speaking to Miss Gale with Clapperton in the street about the time she signed and that she was going to be marriedâ€”I know now her name is Turnerâ€”I knew Mrs. Brown's husband was a sailor, but not that he was abroadâ€”I said yesterday that being a sailor he was probably at seaâ€”I never saw herâ€”I advanced two cheques for Â£225â€”I had the counterfoilâ€”it is not true that she only had Â£189 out of the Â£289 billâ€”I never received back apart of the advanceâ€”I made no stipulations what I should chargeâ€”Clapperton handed me Otine's papersâ€”I did not know it was illegal to lend money on pawn-ticketsâ€”I know nowâ€”I have only had eleven months of this bitter experienceâ€”Clapperton made all arrangementsâ€”he got me to transact Mortimer's business against my wishâ€”he forced me to do itâ€”Â£100 was mentionedâ€”I did not deduct Â£14 11s. from her Â£75â€”she received a Â£75 cheque with Â£25

which was overdueâ€”two transactions were put togetherâ€”I can
not explain why the amount was Â£150â€”nothing his been repaid on that noteâ€”it is not dueâ€”Mrs. Salmon's brooch was stated to contain diamonds and they were not diamondsâ€”I received a bill for Â£72 10s.â€”I do not think I saw any other than Mrs. Salmon, Clapperton and his clerkâ€”I possessed about 130 of these notesâ€”Mrs. Salmon's jewellery was not attached, but Clapperton told me it had goneâ€”I then would have believed everything he saidâ€”I have lost Â£500 or Â£600â€”I was his toolâ€”a letter was written to me by a solicitorâ€”there was a clause for forfeiture of the jewellery if the payments were not kept upâ€”I have a letter stating the jewellery can be given upâ€”I have not sold itâ€”I have a made presents from itâ€”it was in Percy Hilton's nameâ€”he is Clappertonâ€”only two pieces of jewellery are goneâ€”Clapperton's trading as Percy Hilton did not arouse my suspicionsâ€”I heard of Lemere wanting to borrow money about August 16thâ€”Clapperton brought a note of the fur
niture and I took pencil notesâ€”that was about August 29thâ€”the life policy was shown me on August 30thâ€”Lemere made no complaintâ€”in every case an application was made for a loanâ€”I never saw Lemere till he was seeking for meâ€”I never said the life policy could be made of value if the premiums were paidâ€”I was not in favour of these transactions, but Clapperton was so plausibleâ€”I never had an office in Londonâ€”to say the bill of sale was signed by a person unknown to Clapperton is ridiculousâ€”I have the impression that Holloway signed as Lemere and that both the original and copy were signed at the same time, I think in pencilâ€”I could not be positiveâ€”I saw the blank bill of saleâ€”Holloway was presentâ€”I have a distinct impression I saw Percy Hilton signâ€”I could not be positive about Lemereâ€”it may seem strange, but I had such confidence, I took the whole thing as being rightâ€”I remember the signature being put in pencilâ€”Lemere was presentâ€”I am not positive about the word "Lemere" being thereâ€”I am positive about the word "Hilton"â€”I was about two yards offâ€”the man who personated Lemere was not well
known to meâ€”I had never seen him before. (Read from deposition: When I saw him (Holloway) afterwards I saw him in the street round by Benbow Road, and he nodded to me; I believed him to be the real Mr. Lemere. He signed the bill of sale produced in my presence, and it was witnessed by Clapperton in my presence")â€”that is true with regard to Hiltonâ€”I believed Holloway signed as Lemereâ€”I had a thorough impression he had signedâ€”I swore that because when I accepted the bill of sale I accepted it as being signedâ€”Holloway was thereâ€”I was in the Police-court when Mr. Beecher was examinedâ€”I was at Southend when the affidavit was sworn before Mr. Beecherâ€”I know Clapperton proposed to have the bill of sale registered, but that arrangement was departed from when I went to Southendâ€”I left it all to himâ€”the telegram was: "Bill sale registered to-day. Everything in order. Coming to-night or to-morrow.â€”PERCY"â€”I did not know the formalities as to a bill of sale, and I thought as Clapperton was acting for me, it was his duty to inform me.

Re-examined. I have no recollection of any woman putting any other name than her own to a bill of exchangeâ€”I was not present when more than one name was signed except in the case of Collins, when the husband was presentâ€”I saw the bill of sale in preparation by King, Hilton's clerk

in Hilton's officeâ€”it was signed before Holloway, as Lemere, came into the officeâ€”Holloway was introduced as Lemere by Clappertonâ€”he sent me to Southend on September 3rdâ€”I did not know the bill of sale had to be registered within seven days.

SYDENHAM HALL . I am an officer from the Bill of Sale office of the Royal Courts of Justiceâ€”I produce a copy, and the original, bill of sale left for the purpose of filing, together with original affidavit of Percy Hilton on filing same.

GEORGE PERCY BEECHER . I am a medical practitionerâ€”my son Howard Percy Beecher is a commissioner for oathsâ€”he is confined to his bed with typhoid feverâ€”this is his signature to this deposition. (Read: "Howard Percy Beecher, on oath, smith: 'I am a solicitor and com
missioner for oaths. I witnessed the execution of the affidavit produced by the prisoner in the name of Percy Hilton. He was duly sworn. Another man Was with him. The copy bill of sale was signed by the man as Lemere in my presence. The person (Lemere) now in court is not the one who signed the document as Lemere. To the best of my recollection, the man Lemere and prisoner signed the original bill of sale, as well as the copy, in my presence. Looking at the original, I am certain it was signed before me, as some words in the attestation clause were written in by me.â€”H. PERCY BEECHER.")

SIDNEY ARTHUR LEMERK . I am an ex-publicanâ€”I have known Clapperton eighteen months or two years as Percy Hiltonâ€”he was sup
posed to be a money-lenderâ€”in August last I consulted him as to raising a loan of Â£200â€”I was going to add money, and to go into a public-houseâ€”I showed him this life policy as securityâ€”he told me it was waste paper, because it had lapsed six or seven yearsâ€”I thought if I paid the premiums I could renewâ€”I did not know I should have to undergo a fresh medical examinationâ€”he came to my house at 2, Benbow Road, Hammersmith, and took an inventory of my drawing-room furniture onlyâ€”he knew I occupied other rooms, but I did not specify themâ€”after seeing a piano and other furniture, he said, "I have no doubt I can accommodate you"â€”I met him afterwards, when he said he was going in the country, but he would see me laterâ€”that was the end of August or the beginning of Septemberâ€”I called and saw him and his clerkâ€”I did not see Mr. Johnstonâ€”about September 9th he told me he had arranged to make me an advance of Â£200, as a deposit on the public-house, "The Half Moon and Seven Stars,' which was to be paid on the 12th, when I was to be accepted as tenantâ€”he did not turn up that morning, and the deal fell throughâ€”I never executed this bill of sale, and the name is spelt wrongly, "Sydney," instead of "Sidney"â€”this signature not the least, like mineâ€”(This contained an inventory purporting to be of the jurniture of like whole house, and mentioned more rooms and furniture than existed in the house. It was signed"Sydney Lemere"â€”I occupy four roomsâ€”there are eight rooms mentioned in the inventory, including the basement kitchenâ€”when I found it was alleged that I had executed this bill of sale I made inquiriesâ€”I then went to the policeâ€”I never had any of the money.

Cross-examined. The negotiations were going on from the second week in August till December 20thâ€”I knew the life policy had been taken away from my houseâ€”I did not complain to Mr. Johnston, I did not

know himâ€”I asked Hilton to bring the policy back the same night that he had taken it away in the morning, and he said he would send it back by his boyâ€”the day he called to look at my receipts I had gone to the Police-courtâ€”my wife knew where I was, but would not tell himâ€”the bill of sale was taken off the file.

EMMIE LEMERE . I am the wife of Sidney Arthur Lemereâ€”I have seen Hilton (Clapperton) twiceâ€”the first time he called and asked to look at this life policyâ€”I said I did not know anything about itâ€”he saw it lying on the table and took it away, saying "Lemere and I have talked the matter over"â€”about six weeks or two months later he called and asked to see the receipts for rent and taxesâ€”I said Mr. Lemere was out, he had better wait and see him or call againâ€”a man was with him he introduced as Mr. Johnstonâ€”that is not the man (the witness Johniton)â€”nor is Holloway the manâ€”it was about the end of November.

Cross-examined. I said if it was business Mr. Lemere would see about itâ€”that was the first intimation of the bill of sale except my husband tell
ing me about it.

WILLIAM GARDNER . I have lived at 1A, Burymead Road, Acton Green, for eight or nine monthsâ€”no Mr. Ellis lived there during that timeâ€”Holloway lived in the top flatâ€”I have seen Clapperton with Holloway two or three times.

WILLIAM OGBURN . I am manager to Mr. Acton who keeps the "British Prince" public-house, Goldhawk Roadâ€”I have known Clapperton as Percy Hilton for about twelve monthsâ€”he brought me this cheque for Â£200 on September 2ndâ€”it has passed through my employers' bankâ€”lie first asked me if I expected Mr. Acton homeâ€”I said I expected him home the same eveningâ€”he then produced the cheque and asked me to cash itâ€”I said Mr. Acton had told me not to cash chequesâ€”he said he only wanted it cleared and gave me 1s. for the bank to telegraph when it was cleared, and I paid it into the bank with those instructionsâ€”I told Mr. Acton the next morning when the prisoner cameâ€”Mr. Acton sent me to the hank, where I learned the cheque had been met, and Mr. Acton made out the cheque payable to Percy Hiltonâ€”I think it was an open cheque.

p.hi: Clapperton, on the advice of his counsel, tore stated that he was

rs.hi: of forging the bill of sale, and the

div1.p: WILLIAM NOTT (Detective Sergeant, T). I have seen the prisoners together repeatedlyâ€”I held a warrant for the arrest of Clapperton and a wan unknownâ€”on November 30th, at the West London Police-court, I read the warrant to Hollowayâ€”it charged him with conspiracy, with Clapperton, to obtain money by fraudâ€”he said, "I suppose we shall get out of it. I wish I had gone to Buenos Ayres now"â€”he then added, "Â£100 would be a lot"â€”Johnston identified him from about twenty men.

HOLLOWAYâ€”
GUILTY .

p.hi:
A conviction of felony was proved against him.â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

div1.p:
CLAPPERTON, against whom five previous convictions were proved,
Eight Years' Penal Servitude.

div0.p: OLD COURT.â€”Tuesday, December 13th, and Wednesday, December 14th, 1898.

div1.p:
85.
JOHANN SCHNEIDER (36),
alias RICHARD MONTAGUE
,
RICHARD MANDELKOW () was indicted for
, and charged on the Coroner's Inquistion with, the wilful murder of
Conrad Berndt.

p.hi: MR. CHARLES W. MATHEWS, MR. BODKIN

div1.p:
WILLIAM ROSS . I live at 82, William Street, Hampatead Roadâ€”I keep a baker's shopâ€”I have been there 4 1/2 yearsâ€”the shop is on the street level, and is entered through a door from the streetâ€”there is no other door; you have to go through the shop to get to the houseâ€”after going through the shop into the private part of the house there is a staircase going to the first and second floorsâ€”I sleep in the first floor front room; nobody else occupies that floorâ€”on the second floor the servant and two of my children sleep, all in the same roomâ€”there is a back room on the second floor, and the man who works for me sleeps thereâ€”there is nothing above thatâ€”in the basement there is a bakehouse the same size as the shop (you get down to it by the stairs from the back parlour), and behind the counter there is a trap, which lifts up, and through which the bread comesâ€”there is a ladder downâ€”in the bakehouse there is a long baker's ovenâ€”there are also two troughs in front of the ovenâ€”there is whitewash on the wallsâ€”the troughs are for kneadingâ€”there is a clock in the bakehouse, also a window near the cell
ing, it looks out into the area next to the streetâ€”the window is clear glassâ€”you can see into the streetâ€”the top of the window is level with the streetâ€”if you got out at the window you would get into the urea, not on to the pavementâ€”if you were in the street you could see into the bakehouse by looking down the areaâ€”the oven runs back from the roadâ€”in the bake-house a chopper was keptâ€”outside the shop window in the street there is an iron grating in the pavementâ€”it is about 4ft. long by 2ft. wideâ€”when flour comes in it would be lifted up and the flour taken down a pair of stepsâ€”there are two bolts which go through some ringsâ€”it is always kept closed at nightâ€”when it is fastened it is impossible to lift the grat
ingâ€”I always look round before going to bed to see to the fasteningsâ€”the steps hang on to the grating with a chainâ€”I have always had a baker to assist me, he has always lived in the house in the second floor back roomâ€”his duty in the bakehouse would chiefly be at nightâ€”he begins work about 7 o'clock to make the dough, which takes about forty-five minutesâ€”he would use the larger trough for itâ€”after that he goes, up to bed againâ€”he used to have his food in the bakehouseâ€”he gets it him self when he likesâ€”I call him about 11.30 for his night dutiesâ€”he then cuts the same dough back again which takes about half-an-hour, and puts away the ferment for the buns, that takes about five minutesâ€”then he has got nothing to do till about 1 o'clockâ€”he would stay in the bake house and at 1 o'clock he would make the next dough, which takes about half-an-hourâ€”after that he starts the ovenâ€”the fire is on one sideâ€”he heats the oven till about 3.45, when the dough would be put into the ovenâ€”I go to bed about 11.30 after I have called the chap, and get up about

threeâ€”the baker calls meâ€”I go down and help him to get the dough ready for the ovenâ€”the baking continues till about 11 o'clock next morning, my assistant stays there till then, at 11 o'clock all the baking is over for the dayâ€”I have had several assistants, the prisoner was one of themâ€”I knew him by the name of Richard Montague, he worked for me about two years ago for five or six monthsâ€”during that time he lived in my houseâ€”when he came in at 7 o'clock he used to sleep till 11.30â€”I knew he was a married manâ€”he left about two years agoâ€”one day he said he was not well, and I asked him on the Saturday if he would be able to come on the Sunday, and he said, "Yes," but he did not return, he sent another manâ€”I next saw him on November 4th, a Friday, he came about 10 p.m.â€”he said someone had told him that I wanted a man for Saturdayâ€”I said, "No, I don't want anyone, because we are not busy, and we can manage it ourselves"â€”I had not said anything to anybody about wanting a handâ€”he said it was a man in the Christian Lodging-house in Leman Street who told himâ€”I said to him, "Are you hard up?"â€”he said he had been out of work six weeksâ€”I asked him if he would like to take two loaves for his childrenâ€”he took the loaves, and then asked if I would take his addressâ€”I gave him the book which was lying on the counter, and told him to write it downâ€”I was to write to him if I heard of any workâ€”this is the book (Produced)â€”it was written on a loose leaf; it is not there nowâ€”he wrote down, "Richard Montague," I wrote the address, "144, Sewards Street Buildings, Goswell Road"â€”I kept the book in the shop till November 11th, when the police took itâ€”on November 4th I had in my employ a young man named Conrad Berndtâ€”he was about 19 or 20 years oldâ€”he had been with me about seven monthsâ€”he lived in my houseâ€”he slept in the second-floor back bed-roomâ€”he did the baker's dutiesâ€”while at work in the bakehouse he wore a soft cap, a shirt, and a pair of trousers, and a blue-striped canvas belt round his waist with two buckles in itâ€”he was a dark man, with almost black hairâ€”he was a very good workmanâ€”he had other clothes which he went out inâ€”I have seen him wearing a silver watch and chainâ€”he never took it into the bakehouseâ€”I next saw the prisoner on November 10th at 11 p.m. at the shop-doorâ€”I was at the doorâ€”he asked if I would allow him to stop over the night in my bakehouse, as he wanted to go at six o'clock next morning after a place near Oxford Streetâ€”he gave the name of Grummell; it is a baker's shopâ€”he said he was going to see the fore
manâ€”I said, "All right, Richard; I know you, you can come in"â€”he was wearing a hard round hat, and had a green bag in his handâ€”he went round the counter, opened the trap-door, and went down the steps and into the bakehouse, shutting the trap after himâ€”I went upstairsâ€”the gas was alight in the bakehouseâ€”Conrad had been in the bake-house at 7 o'clock, and made the first doughâ€”at 11, when the prisoner called, Conrad was in bed; I had not been down at allâ€”I called Conrad; I went into his roomâ€”he was in bed, not asleepâ€”he rose up in bedâ€”I could only see his shirt; the room was nearly dark, but I could see that the room was tidyâ€”I gave him some instructions, and then left him and then went down to my roomâ€”I heard Conrad come down about five minutes after I had called himâ€”I heard the bakehouse door go as he opened itâ€”nobody else was up thenâ€”I went to bed and to sleepâ€”I had

not been in the bakehouse since the morningâ€”at that time there was nothing over the windowâ€”I was not having any flour in that dayâ€”the grating was fastenedâ€”the chopper was under the troughâ€”after I went to sleep the first thing I heard was someone knocking at the doorâ€”he did not speakâ€”I heard the person then go right down into the bakehouse again by the stairs; I got upâ€”I then saw it was 3.15â€”I dressed and went downstairsâ€”I had a lighted candle in my handâ€”I went through the shop, and looked at the shop clockâ€”I then opened the trap door and went down into the bake-houseâ€”I left the candle on the counter in the shop; I blew it outâ€”I left the trap-door openâ€”the gas was burning in the bakehouseâ€”I stopped on the steps, and called out "Conrad"â€”I got no answer, and then I heard someone on the other side of the bakehouse on the staircaseâ€”I went down, and the prisoner came over from the stairsâ€”he had his coat on, but nothing on his headâ€”I said, "Where is Conrad?"â€”he said, "He has gone upstairs to lie down; he has been sick"â€”I said, "What a funny thing, he has never been sick before, and it is a good thing that you are here"â€”the prisoner spoke is a quiet wayâ€”I then turned towards the oven, I saw that it was alightâ€”there were three cans in front of the oven door which Conrad used to use for himself in the bakehouseâ€”in turning to the oven I should be turning away from the prisonerâ€”I had not gone two steps before I had a blow on the back of my headâ€”I stood for a moment stunned; then I turned round towards the prisoner, and saw he had moved, he was then standing near the troughâ€”he had this life-preserver (Produced) in his handâ€”he had his hands crossed in front of himâ€”I had never seen the life-preserver beforeâ€”it is not mineâ€”I rushed by him and up the staircase which he had come downâ€”when I got half-way up I called "Police"â€”the prisoner came after me and put his arm round meâ€”the only light on the stairs would shine through the bakehouse doorâ€”then I felt the point of a knife in my chestâ€”I seized it with my right hand and kept on pushing the prisoner back with my left down the stairsâ€”I heard my wife and servant calling out upstairsâ€”the prisoner pulled the knife through my hand and ran down into the bakehouseâ€”he took the knife with himâ€”my hand was cut very muchâ€”I went through the shop, opened the door, went outside and called out "Police" and "Murder"â€”while I was doing that the grating outside the shop window flew open and the prisoner jumped outâ€”that was about two minutes after I had got to the doorâ€”the grating could not have been fastenedâ€”the prisoner ran down William Street to
wards Hampstead Roadâ€”Constable Chrisp came up and afterwards In
spector Goughâ€”I found my head was bleeding and both my hands were outâ€”Dr. Maughan came to my house and attended to my injuriesâ€”I after
wards went into the bakehouse and saw that the dough which had been made at eight o'clock the night before had been cut backâ€”the bun ferment had not been preparedâ€”about three-quarters of an hour's work had been doneâ€”the window was covered with a flour-sackâ€”the top of the window was pinching the sack between itself and the top of the window-frameâ€”I had never seen it done beforeâ€”I also looked at the book on the shop counter, and found part of the page where the prisoner's name had been written torn out, as it is nowâ€”the blood on the book came from my

handsâ€”this round felt hat (produced) is the prisoner'sâ€”it was left behind in the bakehouseâ€”this chopper (produced) is mineâ€”it was left in the bakehouse on that eveningâ€”these two buckles had been on Conrad's beltâ€”this piece of charred cloth is a piece of the trousers Conrad used to wear, and also this piece of beltâ€”this green-baize bag is the one the prisoner was carrying on that nightâ€”this watch and chain and seal belonged to Conradâ€”I have never seen the knife beforeâ€”all the money I take in my business I take up to my bedroom every night about 11 o'clock, and it remains there till next morningâ€”I pay it away to the millers as soon as I can; I have no banking accountâ€”on this night I had between Â£20 and Â£25 in my houseâ€”when I go down to the bakehouse at 3 o'clock I used sometimes one staircase and sometimes the other.

Cross-examined. As a rule I go into the bakehouse during the day to see how things are going onâ€”the gas is always burning down thereâ€”on the morning before the murder I was down in the bakehouse with Conradâ€”I saw the hatchet there under the troughâ€”there was nothing over the window thenâ€”we never put anything over the windowâ€”after the prisoner left my employment two years ago I did not see him again till November 4thâ€”I inquired for him during the first weekâ€”I found out he was ill, not buffering from his headâ€”he said he had done himself harm by lifting a sackâ€”I saw him every day whilst he was with meâ€”when I saw him on November 4th I did not notice that his manners had changed at allâ€”he was perfectly quietâ€”during the seven months he was with me there was nothing to be frightened of about himâ€”on November 11th when he came he was perfectly quietâ€”when he struck me he made no soundâ€”I was struck by the life-preserver, not the hatchetâ€”when I turned round he was about two yards away from meâ€”he stared at me for about two minutes before I made the rush for the stairs; till then he did not make any step towards meâ€”he was dressed, but had no hat onâ€”the first time I knew he had a knife in his hand was when he put his arm round me on the stairsâ€”it only penetrated the skinâ€”I was wearing a shirt and an under-shirtâ€”when I went up to Conrad's room the night before to call him, it was nearly dark, but I could see it was tidy because the lamps in the street were shining into the roomâ€”flour comes in about once a fortnightâ€”nothing else comes down through the gratingâ€”Conrad fixed the barâ€”if I know that the bolts were fixed, and nothing had gone through I do not look at them; if they are safe in the morning I should not go round in the evening.
Re-examined. I asked the man who the prisoner sent to do his work when he went away, how Richard was getting on, and he said, "I don't think he will come back again."

EVA MILLER . I am a servant in the employ of Mr. Rossâ€”I have been with him for about three yearsâ€”it was part of my duty to attend to the room occupied by the assistant in the businessâ€”I used to go into the room occupied by Conrad Berndt to make it tidyâ€”he had a box in the room in which he kept his best clothesâ€”there was also a cupboard where he kept a suit which he wore for second lestâ€”his room was always nice and tidyâ€”he used to wear a silver watch and chain and sealâ€”as a rule they were kept in the cupboard in the waistcoat of his second best

suitâ€”I never knew him to wear them in the bakehouseâ€”when at work he used to wear a shirt with blue and white stripesâ€”this burnt piece is a part of his shirt (produced)â€”he always wore a belt, he had two, one was leather and the other of a striped materialâ€”one of the belts had two buckles, one large and one smallâ€”these (produced) are the two buckles and this is a part of the beltâ€”I saw Conrad on the 10th after he bad had supper and before he went up to bedâ€”I saw him going up to bed, he had his bakehouse clothes on, he had no waistcoat on, that was the last I saw of himâ€”my room was quite close to hisâ€”about 3 o'clock I heard a noise on the stairs, I had been asleepâ€”I went downstairs, by that time the police had arrivedâ€”I accompanied one of the police-officers into Conrad's roomâ€”it was very untidyâ€”the box had been opened and the clothes were on the bedâ€”they were searched by the police., and a purse was found in the trousers' pocketâ€”it was shut, but was opened in my presence, and Â£5 5s. was found in itâ€”in the box was a cigar box in which Conrad used to keep some cotton and needles, and some moneyâ€”he generally kept most of the money in the purseâ€”the cupboard was openâ€”these are Conrad's watch and chain and seal.

WILLIAM GRIST (265 s). On November 11th, about 3 a.m., I was on duty near the Hampstead Roadâ€”I heard cries of "Police!" and "Murder!"â€”I ran to the shop of Mr. Ross, and saw him standing against his shop doorâ€”he was bleeding from a wound at the back of his headâ€”Inspector Gough came up, and I was sent for Dr. Maughanâ€”I brought him back with meâ€”the inspector and I then searched the house trying to find Conrad Berndtâ€”we went down into the bakehouse, and saw that the fire in the oven was alightâ€”in front of the oven there were three cansâ€”the oven was very hot, with the assistance of an iron bur we opened the oven door, and saw lying inside the oven the remains of a human bodyâ€”under directions I cooled the oven as rapidly as I could, and afterwards assisted other officers to remove the remains from the oven.

ALBERT JOHN HEARN (60 s). I was on duty in the Hampstead Road on November 11th, between 3 and 3.30 a.m.â€”William Street turns at right angles from Hampstead Road, and leads up to Cumberland Marketâ€”I saw the prisoner in George Street, which is hardly a quarter of a mile from William Streetâ€”he came hurrying towards me from Tolmer Square, which is on the opposite side of the street to William Streetâ€”I noticed that he was very much excitedâ€”he had no hat onâ€”I went towards him, and said, "Halloa, what is the matter I"â€”he made no reply, but turned and ran towards the Euston Roadâ€”I ran after himâ€”Constable Westcote was with meâ€”while the prisoner was running in front of me I saw him throw something awayâ€”I did not see what it wasâ€”I caught him by Gower Street Stationâ€”I said, "What have you been doing?"â€”he said, "Nothing"â€”we took him back into George Street, and searched about where we had seen the prisoner throw some
thing awayâ€”we found this knife (Produced) lying in the street openâ€”I noticed that it had wet stains on it, apparently of bloodâ€”I said to the prisoner, "What have you been doing with this?"â€”he said, "It is not my knife"â€”we took him to the stationâ€”on the way I noticed his hands were wet with bloodâ€”I asked him how he got itâ€”he said, "I must have got it last night, I was drunk"â€”I asked him, "Where were you going

when I first saw you?â€”he said he was going to work at the Meat Market in Farringdon Streetâ€”the front of his clothes was all whiteâ€”Westcote asked him what it wasâ€”he said he must have got it leaning against a whitewashed wallâ€”at the station Inspector Kerswell was in charge.

Cross-examined. When the prisoner turned to run away he was about six yards offâ€”there was nothing very extraordinary about his appearance, he looked very excited, he looked as if he had been having a fightâ€”he was panting and wild-looking about the face, he looked frightened as if he was afraid of meeting some oneâ€”he looked frightened when I first saw himâ€”he went to the station quietly with one of us on each side of him we were both holding himâ€”he was quiet in the stationâ€”he looked agitatedâ€”I did not have any conversation with him thereâ€”I did not see the knife in his handâ€”I did not see if he took it out of his pocket.
JEREMIAH WESTCOTE (64 s). In the early morning of November 11th I was in company with Constable Hearn, I saw the prisoner in George Street and assisted in his capture.

Cross-examined. When I first saw him he was looking very excited, he looked so before the other policeman spoke to himâ€”he was hurrying before we spoke to him, he commenced to run when we spoke to himâ€”he was going about six or seven miles an hour and when we spoke he began to runâ€”he was coming towards usâ€”he was on the opposite side of the road, he went on in the direction he was going which would take him into the Euston Roadâ€”we ran after him for about fifty yards, when he was stopped he came quietly to the stationâ€”on the way I noticed some white marks on his clothing and I asked him what it was, he said it was white-washâ€”he said he got it from getting over a wallâ€”he was not excited when he said thatâ€”people running from the police are generally excited under those circumstances.

JOHN KERSWELL (Inspector S). In the early morning of November 11th I was on duty at the Albany Street Police-stationâ€”about 3.20 the prisoner was brought in by the last two witnessesâ€”they told me in his presence that they had seen him running, and thinking that something was wrong, they ran after him, and immediately they ran after him he threw something awayâ€”they showed me this open knife; it was wet on the blade as though with bloodâ€”I asked the prisoner whose knife it wasâ€”he said, "It id mine"â€”I noticed that his clothes were covered with what looked like flourâ€”I asked him what it wasâ€”he said, "I was drunk last night; I leant against a wall and got the whitewash on me"â€”I examined his hands, and on his right hand he had bloodâ€”I asked him how he accounted for the blood, and he again replied, "I was drunk last night, and must have cut myself"â€”I said, Why were you running?"â€”he said, "I was not running; I was hurrying to get to work; I am a butcher, and work at Farringdon Meat Market"â€”I tried two or three times to close the knife, and the prisoner volunteered to show me the way to close itâ€”he took the knife, placed the back of it. against the iron rail of our dock, and pressed it, the spring is very stiff, and so closed itâ€”about five or ten minutes after the prisoner was brought in Sergeant Lubley came in with a message from Inspector Gough, the prisoner was sitting down thenâ€”

on the piece of paper which Mr. Gough had sent me was a name and address, and the description of a man wanted, "R. Montague, 121 or 141, Sewards Buildings, Goswell Road"â€”I said to the prisoner, "Your name is Montague t"â€”he immediately replied, "No, my name is Schneider, and I am a Russian, and I live at 15, Regent's Park Road"â€”soon after that Inspector Gough came to the station and saw the prisonerâ€”he then left and shortly returned with Mr. Ross and Dr. Maughanâ€”I then searched the prisoner, and in the outside breast pocket of his coat I found this watch and chain and sealâ€”I asked him whose they wereâ€”he replied, "It id mine, I bought it about two years ago"â€”I also found on him two pieces of paperâ€”this is one of them (read): "121, Bartholomew Buildings, Seward Street, Goswell Road, E.C.: R. Mandel
kow"â€”I also found this piece of paper (read): "Schneider, Cabel"â€”I told the prisoner that 150, Regent's Park Road was a shopâ€”he replied, "No, it is not; I have lived there for the past two months"â€”I then entered the charge in the charge-bookâ€”I charged him with wilful murder, and also attempting to murder Mr. Rossâ€”I asked him again for his name and address, and he gave Johann Schneider, 150, Regent's Park Roadâ€”is answer to the charge he said, "I know nothing about it; I do not know the shop."

Cross-examined. I did not consider him excited when he was brought in at 3.30â€”he was not put into the cells till 7 a.m.â€”he was in my pre
sence the greater part of that timeâ€”when he was put into the cells he appeared more excited than at firstâ€”he looked as if he felt his position he looked wilderâ€”he did not look wild when he first came inâ€”he had a rather vacant expression and a glaring expressionâ€”he looked with a wild glaring look as if he had something on his mindâ€”he had a depressed lookâ€”he did not say anything wildâ€”I mean to say that being depressed and downcast and glaring and vacant and wild mean the same thing.

JOHN GOUGH (Inspector S Division). About 3.15 on November 11th I was in Stanhope Streetâ€”I heard cries of "Murder" and "Police"â€”I went to 82, William Streetâ€”outside the house I saw Mr. Ross standing and P.C. Gristâ€”Mr. Ross was bleeding from the back of his head and his handsâ€”I sent Grist for Dr. Maughan and I accompanied Mr. Ross into the houseâ€”the constable returned with the doctorâ€”we then proceeded to search the houseâ€”on the stairs leading from the house to the bakehouse I found this hatchetâ€”there was some hair on the head of it; it did not look like human hairâ€”blood was on the handle where it fits into the headâ€”it was wetâ€”the doctor took the hair off it, and has got it nowâ€”on the floor of the bakehouse I found this roughly-made life-preserverâ€”it is composed of a piece of lead with a piece of round, and attached by a piece of string to a short rope handleâ€”on the rag when I discovered it, I found a wet spot of bloodâ€”we were then trying to find Conrad Berndtâ€”Grist and I went to the oven, which was heatedâ€”I told Grist to open the door with an iron barâ€”inside we found the remains of a man very much charred and burntâ€”the body had been placed about 2ft. 6in. inâ€”the head was towards the doorâ€”the skull was bared and broken on the right sideâ€”I gave directions for the fire to he drawnâ€”Grist did soâ€”about 5 a.m. I went to the bakehouse again, with Dr. Maughan, the fire was still burning very fiercely, we could not get

near the body thenâ€”we returned again when the oven had cooled, and then in the presence of the doctor, and under his directions, we removed the body from the oven and placed it in a shellâ€”I saw that one of the kneading troughs was damp near the oven-door, as though it had been washed, and on the damp were some faint stains like bloodâ€”on the wall above the trough there were some splashes of blood; they were dry thenâ€”on a shelf I found this brown hard felt hatâ€”on a stone in the ash
pit, under the oven, was more bloodâ€”I went to Conrad's roomâ€”on the bed I saw a-suit of clothes, and in the breast pocket of the coat I found this receipt for a watchâ€”the box in the room was openâ€”the room was in great disorderâ€”I then found that the prisoner was already in custody, and I was present when he was charged with this murderâ€”in answer to the charge he said, "I know nothing about it. I do not know the shop"â€”a document was found on the prisoner giving his address as ill, Bartholomew Buildingsâ€”I went thereâ€”he occupied two rooms thereâ€”I saw the bedstead in the bedroomâ€”it had originally four brass knobsâ€”it was an iron bedstead, with brass knobsâ€”when I saw it it had only two; I took off one of the remaining ones (produced)â€”the lead forming the head of the life-preserver appears exactly like the brass knobs, as if the lead had been moulded in a corresponding knobâ€”I also brought away two pieces of brass, and in the bottom of one of the knobs was a piece of lead.
Cross-examined. I did not see the prisoner until just before he was charged except for a few seconds.

FRANCIS BOSWRLL (Sergeant S). On November 11th about 5.20 a.m., I went to 82, William Street, Hampstead Roadâ€”I assisted in the removal of the remains from the ovenâ€”Dr. Maughan superintended the removalâ€”afterwards the burnt ashes in the mouth of the oven were swept outâ€”I turned them over with my handâ€”a quantity of bones reduced almost to ashes were found, and also two buckles; these are the bucklesâ€”to the larger one a piece of coarse canvas was attached, also a portion of a trouser buttonâ€”in the box in the deceised's room I found a savings' bank book in the name of Conrad Berndt, showing that he had about Â£15 to his creditâ€”in the packet of the trousers on the bed I found a leather purse containing Â£; in gold and a crown pieceâ€”there was besides the suit, a hat and a shirt on the bed.

JAMES MAUGHAN . I am a Bachelor of Medicine, a Member of the College of Surgeons, an L.C.P. and divisional surgeon to the S Division of policeâ€”on the early morning of November 11th I was called to William Streetâ€”in the parlour I saw Mr. Rossâ€”he had a wound on the scalp at the back of the head, exposing the bone, and a swelling in front of the left eye; on the right hand, between the thumb and forefinger, an incised wound, two and a-half inches long; on the right elbow five abrasions; on the left palm an incised wound three inches long; a second wound on the left hand between the thumb and forefinger; a punctured wound on the chest, a skin wound onlyâ€”it was in a dangerous placeâ€”if it had been deep it would have been dangerousâ€”in his shirt and vest I found cuts corresponding with the cut on his chestâ€”they could have been caused by this knifeâ€”I wound into the bakehouse and looked into the ovenâ€”it was heated to about; 600 degrees Fahrenheitâ€”I saw a human body lying about two and a-half feet insideâ€”the hair of the head had been burned

offâ€”the bones were exposedâ€”the head was retracted and the bones charredâ€”after some delay the oven was cooled, and the remains taken out and placed in a shell, and I examined themâ€”in the bakehouse there it a large trough, and one end joins on to the oven, and on the wall by it I saw some splashes of bloodâ€”there were hairs on the wall, and it looked as if the wall had recently been wiped with something wetâ€”the hairs were very dark and very healthyâ€”the lid of the trough was damp and there were blood stains faintly showing through as if it had been wiped with something wetâ€”on a piece of wood above the trough I found a piece of human brain with recent blood stains on it and weighing 57 grainsâ€”on a large stone under the oven I saw blood which had recently fallen on it and I found a piece of brain weighing 10 grainsâ€”the trough and the wall had been sprinkled with flour over the stainsâ€”on the hatchet there were spots of blood and on the middle part of the head there was something fluffyâ€”the handle had been recently washed, but blood stains were clearly perceptibleâ€”I was also shown a clasp-knife and found blood stains on itâ€”on the piece of material over the lead of the life preserver were two stains which were found to be bloodâ€”that was such an imple
ment as would have inflicted the blow on Mr. Ross's head the remains were removed to the mortuary, and on November 12th, assisted by Doctor Jackson Clarke, I made a post-mortem examination and we arrived at the conclusion that death was caused by the fracture of the skull, which caused extensive bleeding on the surface of the brain, in consequence of which there was failure of the respiratory centre, or asphyxiaâ€”unconciousness was probably immediate, and then deathâ€”the fracture was caused by some person other than than deceasedâ€”the broad end of the head of the chopper was such an instrument as would produce the injury found on the deceased's headâ€”the deceased was probably lying down, or his head was resting against a firm substanceâ€”the blow was de
livered on the right side of the headâ€”I think the man must have lived about half an hour after the blowâ€”I do not think he would have re
covered consciousness; he would not have been conscious when placed in the ovenâ€”on the early morning of the 11th I examined the prisoner at the stationâ€”on his right hand there were recent blood stainsâ€”across the palm there was a recent burn about 2 ins. long and 1/4 in. broad, and across the finger tips, except the middle finger which was gone, there was another recent burnâ€”on the inner side of the palm of the left hand there was a narrow burn 2 1/2 ins. long, and a blister and a scorch, both recentâ€”the left arm from elbow to wrist was smudged with wet bloodâ€”his left coat sleeve and vest sleeve were stained with bloodâ€”I saw some white marks on him, and I took some scrapings off them, and also off a sack in the bakehouse, and the two corresponded exactlyâ€”while I was doing that the prisoner said, "Oh, that is only a little whitewash that I got from a wall lost night."â€”he offered no explanation as to the burn or blisters.

Cross-examined. He did not appear to be suffering pain at allâ€”insane people are less susceptible to painâ€”in certain kinds of insanity there is a total absence of painâ€”he had a fit at the Police-court, whilst the evidence was being givenâ€”I attended him, and he recoveredâ€”it is quite possible for a person to commit an act, and a short time after to be quite un
conscious of having done it.

Re-examined. The fit at the Court I put down to lack of proper self
control; the evidence had been particularly painful, and he could not control his emotionâ€”it was not through an impaired intellect.

SAMUEL FELDT . I am an Hungarian, and live at 77, Mile End Roadâ€”in November last I made the acquaintance of the prisoner; he told me his name was Richard Mandeckow, and that he was a Germanâ€”I was then living at 141, Bartholomew Buildings, and the prisoner was living in the same houseâ€”on November 6th we were together in my roomâ€”I opened my trunk where I kept this knife produced, which I had bought about two years agoâ€”I took the knife out and gave it to the prisoner, it was a free gift, I had no use for itâ€”he took it away with him, and I did not see it againâ€”I saw him every day till the 10thâ€”I saw him on the 10th about 10 o'clock, he said he was going to work somewhere for the night, with a baker at Islingtonâ€”he left the house that nightâ€”he was wearing a hat like this, and he took his green baize bagâ€”that is the last I saw of him until he was in custody.

Cross-examined. I had seen him frequently during the time I knew himâ€”he was morose, downcast, and absent-mindedâ€”he never knew what we were talking aboutâ€”he was depressed because of his poverty and because he could not find work, and he has three children and a wifeâ€”sometimes he would sit for hours in a corner by himself without speaking to anybodyâ€”he did not know what we said to him, we always had to repeat itâ€”we made him understand at last.
Re-examined. He used to go out and try to get work, and read the advertisements in the newspapers; he said he could not find itâ€”I only knew him from November 5th to the 10th.

PETER VOLHAUSER . I am a foreman baker to Messrs. Grummell and Sons, 12, Nassau Street, Sohoâ€”the prisoner did not apply to us on November 11th for work or on any other dayâ€”I do not know him, and we had no vacancy.
JOHN LEINVER . I am foreman baker to Messrs. Grummell, of 4, Mackle Street, Sohoâ€”I do not know the prisonerâ€”he did not apply to us for employment, we had no vacancy.

JAMES SCOTT . I am medical officer at Hollo way prisonâ€”the prisoner was received there on November 11thâ€”in consequence of instructions I have made him a special subject for observation since thenâ€”in my opinion he was sane on his reception, and has remained sane since.

Cross-examined. To some extent he is an emotional manâ€”when he first came to the prison he looked rather thinâ€”an insane person is not so susceptible to pain as a sane personâ€”I have watched him narrowly.

JOHN HENRY PARKER WILSON , F.R.C.S. At different times the prisoner has been under my medical observationâ€”he was so from, May to November, 1897â€”I did not see anything tending to show that he was not saneâ€”I had constant observation of himâ€”he was again under my observation from September 3rd to November 2nd, 1898â€”during that time I saw nothing in his demeanour to indicate that he was other than of a sound mind.
Cross-examined. I only saw him in an ordinary manner, no special watch was kept on himâ€”I used to see him about three times a dayâ€”during the day I should see between 200 and 300 people.
