Re-examined. If there had been any indication of insanity in him my attention would have been directed to itâ€”the least little matter is always brought to my notice by those under meâ€”I should not put him under, special observation unless there was some reason for it.

GUILTY.â€”
DEATH .

86.
ANDREW WOOD (29), was indicted
for a rape on
Annie Mary Webster.

The prisoner war tried at the last Sessions, and the Jury, not being able to agree, were discharged without returning any verdict. Upon again being placed at the bar, MR. HUTTON, for tilted prosecution, offered no evidence, and the JURY found him
NOT GUILTY .

87.
ATHALIE GOODMAN MILLS and
KATE LYON
were, charged upon the Coroner's Inquisition only with the manslaughter of
Harold Frederick.
MR. HORACE AVOBY, for the prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

88.
WILLIAM GEORGE HANNA (55)
, unlawfully committing certain lewd practices in a public place.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”
One Month without Hard Labour.

89.
OTTO SCHMIDT (25)
, manslaughter of
Wilhelm Harmann.
MR. GEOGHEGAN, for the defence, stated that the prisoner would

PLEAD GUILTY to an assault, and
MR. BIRON, for the prosecution, accepted that plea.â€”
Discharged on his own recognisances.

div0.p: OLD COURT.â€”Friday, December 16th, 1898, and following days.

div1.p:
90.
RICHARD CHRIMES (32),
EDWARD CHRIMES (31), and
LEONARD CHRIMES (22)
, feloniously sending to
Kate Clifford a letter demanding money from her, under the threat of exposing her for taking certain drugs when with child, to procure her miscarriage, to which

EDWARD and LEONARD CHRIMES
PLEADED GUILTY .
MR. CHARLES MATHEWS and MR. MUIR Prosecuted; MR. WADDY appeared for Richard Chrimes, MR. WILBERPORCE for Edward Chrimes, and MR. A. HUTTON for Leonard Chrimes.

p.hi: The particulars of this case are unfit for publication.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”RICHARD CHRIMESâ€”
Twelve Years' Penal Servitude.

EDWARD CHRIMESâ€”
Twelve Years' Penal Servitude.

LEONARD CHRIMESâ€”
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

91.
JOHN EAST (34)
PLEADED GUILTY
to marrying
Ellen Goddard, his wife being alive.â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour. And

92.
GEORGE ALBERT GROSSMAN (27)
, to marrying
Annie Osborne, his wife being alive, having been convicted of felony on April 21st, 1892.â€”
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

92.
WALTER WYLIE (30) and
JOHN JAMES (52)
, burglary in the dwelling-house of
William Hepworth Dickson, and stealing a teapot and other articles, his property.

WYLIE
PLEADED GUILTY .

WILLIAM HEPWORTH DICKSON . I am a match manufacturer, of Ingle
ton, Red bridge Lane, Wansteadâ€”on November 29th I went to bed about 10 o'clockâ€”all the fastenings on the doors and windows were safeâ€”about 2.30 I was awakened by my wifeâ€”I heard noises down stairsâ€”I got out of bed, and went on to the landingâ€”the drawing-room door was openâ€”it was closed when I went to bedâ€”I heard a conversation going on in one of the roomsâ€”I shouted out, "Who is there, what do you want?"â€”I got no replyâ€”we raised an alarmâ€”then I went down stairs, and saw a man running awayâ€”I went into the kitchen where I noticed a case of pro
visions, which had just been got inâ€”then I went in to the dining-roomâ€”I found all the silver had been taken out of the cupboard and packed up in an anti-macassar off a chairâ€”the police arrived, and Wylie was brought into the house, and then to the stationâ€”I went with himâ€”while I was there James was brought in, and I identified as mine two odd boots which he had onâ€”he also had a bottle of whiskey and a box of cigarettesâ€”I had had a bottle of the same kind, and also some cigarettesâ€”at the time I valued the property at Â£40, but I think now it is worth a good deal moreâ€”some boots were found in the dust-binâ€”the prisoners did hot say whose they were.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. At the Police-court I said I thought the maker's name was in the bootsâ€”no name was in themâ€”you were brought to the station about 4.30.

WILLIAM BRAND (401 G). I am stationed at Wansteadâ€”on November 30th, about 4 a.m., I went with Wilde to the prosecutor's house, and found that an entry had been made through the kitchen windowâ€”I saw Wylie arrestedâ€”I then went into some unfinished buildings in Martha Road, near the scene of the burglary, and saw James behind some timberâ€”I turned my light out him, and noticed that he was wearing a pair of boots which were not in keeping with his general appearanceâ€”I caught hold of him and said, "I want you out of here"â€”he struggled to get awayâ€”I got him out of the building, and outside he produced a bottle of whisky and said, "Can you do a drop of whisky"â€”I said, "Yes, later

on"â€”we then walked some distance down the road and I told him that he would be charged on suspicion with having committed a burglaryâ€”he said, "You are artful: if I had known that, you would never have got me out of the hoarding, but I will be level with you yet, and the first time we meet you will know what to expect"â€”I took him to the station where he was charged, he made no replyâ€”I was present when the prosecutor identified the boots and the whiskyâ€”I heard no statement about the boots.
Cross-examined. I found you about 4.40.

GEORGE WILDE (Police Sergeant 72 J). I am stationed at Wansteadâ€”on Wednesday morning, November 30th, I went to the prosecutor's houseâ€”I found a burglary had been committedâ€”I went into the kitchen and I found a box had been broken openâ€”I looked into the dustbin and found two pairs of bootsâ€”I took them to the stationâ€”I was present when the prisoner was brought inâ€”the property was identified by Mr. Dickaonâ€”before taking the prisoner to the Police-court we removed the boots, belonging to the prosecutorâ€”the prisoner had then no boots, and I told him to put on the boots I had found in the dustbinâ€”they fitted him.
Cross-examined. You said the boots were not yoursâ€”I said. "If you don't put them on you will have to go without any"â€”you were brought in about 5.15.

p.hi: The Prisoner, in his defence, said thai he had bought the boots and whisky at Stratford; that he had lost his way, and was sleeping under the hoarding, and that he had never been convicted before.

div1.p: WILLIAM DICKSON (Re-examined). The boots were worth about the pair.

GUILTY ,â€”Four previous convictions were proved against JAMES.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

WYLIEâ€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

94.
EDWARD CARNEY (46)
, carnally knowing
Mary Carney, a girl under the age of 13 years.
NOT GUILTY .

95.
ARTHUR SIMMONS (24)
PLEADED GUILTY
to unlawfully having counterfeit coin in his possession with intent to utter it.â€”
One Months' Hard Labour.

96.
HENRY GREEN (26)
, carnally knowing
Ellen Andrews, a girl between the age of 13 and 16.

97.
JOHN SAMUEL BULLOCK (45)
, feloniously killing and slay
ing
Joseph Frederick James Crumpton.

JUSTINIAN PICKARD (85 M). Produced and proved the plan of South
wark Bridge, showing that the deceased fell 23 1/2 feet.

JAMES MURPHY . I am 13; I knew the little boy Crumpton, I went to school with himâ€”on November 5th I went out with a guy, and went on to Southwark Bridgeâ€”I saw the prisoner coming over the bridge, and asked him to remember the guy, and he made a hit at me, but I dodged himâ€”he went up to the guy, and pulled the nose off and went on over ihe bridgeâ€”shortly afterwards I saw some people carrying the boy away.

Cross-examined. The prisoner was on the right-hand side of the bridgeâ€”Crumpton was not with me thenâ€”there were a lot of guys on the bridgeâ€”I did not run towards the prisonerâ€”I went up to him and said, "Please remember the guy"â€”the boys were not shouting.

THOMAS ALLISTON . I am ten years old, and live at 22, Moss Alley, Banksideâ€”I was out with a guy on November 5th on Southwark Bridgeâ€”I know Crumptonâ€”he was on the bridge on November 5th, on the right sideâ€”I was on the leftâ€”he was crawling along the parapetâ€”there was another guy there, near himâ€”the prisoner came along, and when he got near Crumpton he hit him with his fist, and he fell overâ€”the prisoner was drunkâ€”I did not call after him when he passed me, nor did Crumpton.
Cross-examined. The boys were calling out, "Please to remember the 5th of November"â€”they gathered round the prisonerâ€”he did not push the boys awayâ€”he was walking close to the parapet.
Re-examined. He hit the boy on his sideâ€”I did not see Crumpton do anythingâ€”he was crawling on his hands and knees.

ALBERT EDWARD ROBINS . I am a labourer, of 67, Ancoras Street, Kingslandâ€”on November 5th, soon after one, I was on the left-hand side of Southwark Bridge, going towards the Cityâ€”I saw a number of boys and some guysâ€”one boy was in a lying position on the parapetâ€”I was about 100 yards offâ€”I saw the prisoner push the boy over the parapet with his right armâ€”I ran across the road and caught hold of the prisoner and asked him what he had done it forâ€”he said, he could not help it, he did not mean to do itâ€”he was drunkâ€”I held him till the police came up.
Cross-examined. The first thing 'I saw was the pushâ€”it was not a blowâ€”it might be a blow and a hit at the same time.
Re-examined. I had not seen the boy beforeâ€”I did not see if the man's hand was closed or notâ€”he knew what he was about.
By the JURY. I did not see any provocation givenâ€”the prisoner was not helpless drunk.

LILIAN KEYS I live at 7, Cardwell Streetâ€”I was on the approach to Southwark Bridge on this day, coming from the Cityâ€”I was with a friend named Maudeâ€”I saw the prisoner coming along reeling as if drunkâ€”I saw a little boy crawling on the parapet and the prisoner made a step towards him, hit him in the side and knocked him over the parapetâ€”I was about two yards awayâ€”I had not seen the boy do or say anythingâ€”

the prisoner looked over to see where the boy had fallen and staggered backâ€”my friend rushed up to him and held him tightâ€”he struggled a little and a gentleman came up and held himâ€”he said, "Let me go, miss; I have not done anything"â€”my friend said, "Too shall not go, you wretch, till a constable comes"â€”I saw him taken away by the police.

Cross-examined. I did not know Crumpton or the prisonerâ€”there were some boys and guys on the bridgeâ€”I was very angry at the timeâ€”I did not see the prisoner do anything to the other boys, because there was a bendâ€”the prisoner leaned over the parapet after the boy had gone over.

WILLIAM HUMPHRIES . I am a carpenter, of 6, North Roadâ€”on Novem
ber 5th I was working for Day and Martin'sâ€”they have premises at the side of the buildingâ€”I heard a thud, and I saw a little boy near me on the pavementâ€”it was in an alley paved with graniteâ€”he was removed to the hospital.
Cross-examined. I had before that seen some boys playing on the wall, and had warned them to stop.

GEORGE WATKINS (587 City). I took the prisoner into custody on November 5thâ€”he said he pushed the boy, but the boy pushed him firstâ€”he was drunkâ€”I took him to the stationâ€”he was very violent on the way.

PHILIP TURNER . I am house-surgeon at Guy's Hospitalâ€”Crumpton was brought in on November 5thâ€”he was unconsciousâ€”he had a fractured skull, and there was a large surface of bone three inches by two and a-half inches depressedâ€”he died on November 8thâ€”I made a post-mortem examination, and found that death was caused by the fractured skull.

GUILTY.â€”Strongly recommended to mercy by the JURY.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

98.
HARRY UGLOW (25)
, carnally knowing
Kate Bertha Lock, a girl between 13 and 16 years of age.
NOT GUILTY .

99.
DANIEL GREATOREX (37)
, unlawfully having counterfeit coin in his possession with intent to utter it.

WILLIAM WILLIAMSON (Detective Sergeant). On November 10th about 8.30, I was in Guildford Street, Borough, disguised, and saw the prisoner and a womanâ€”I had had them under observation for several weeksâ€”the woman sat on a door-step; the prisoner left her and went to a house and then came and sat by the side of her and a man not in custodyâ€”the man said, "God blind me, I nearly had rumble yesterday; the old woman kept looking at the coin and at me, but she took it and gave me the change"â€”I did not catch the replyâ€”I followed behind them and saw the man not in custody pass something to herâ€”she said, "How much do you want now?"â€”he then took something out and joined the other man

and I saw money pass, but whether that was before or after he handed him the parcel I cannot sayâ€”I was alone at that timeâ€”about 9 the same evening we saw the two prisoners together but did not take actionâ€”on the 15th we saw them together again, the female prisoner (See next case) sitting on the same door-stepâ€”Cox arrested her about 8 30â€”he was standing about eighty yards from herâ€”I went and saw him in conversa
tion with another manâ€”I said, "There is a woman locked up there"â€”he said, "That is my old woman"â€”he ran and struck the constable, and I arrested him, and told him I was a police officerâ€”on the way to the station he said, "I should like to know who has put us up"â€”he was very violentâ€”when charged he said to Sergeant Cox, "This is the bâ€”case you have had, and I know who gave you the information"â€”I found some good money on him.

DAVID COX (Police Sergeant L). On November 15th I was in Guild
ford Street with other officers, and saw Lawrence sitting on a stepâ€”I arrested her she became very violent, and threw herself on the groundâ€”the prisoner came up and struck me in the face, saying, "Take that!"â€”Sergeant Webb knocked him downâ€”I received from the female searcher two parcels, containing fourteen half-crown and ten shillings wrapped up separately.

WILLIAM BIRCH (Detective Officer). I assisted in taking Lawrenceâ€”she was very violent, and threw herself down and kicked usâ€”they were both charged togetherâ€”Lawrence gave me a purse containing good moneyâ€”she said, "You might be clever, but you have not got all what you would like now."
ALICE SHANK . I am female searcher at Southwark Police-courtâ€”I found Lawrence in a cell on November 15th. and she handed me this parcel of counterfeit coin (produced).

WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am inspector of coin to Her Majesty's Mint; these fourteen half-crowns are all counterfeit and made from One mould, and these ten shillings are bad and made from one mouldâ€”they are wrapped up in the usual way.

Prisoner's defence. I do not know anything about the parcels. I came out of a public-house, and he was nearly breaking the woman's arm I said, "Why don't you let the woman go?"and they shoved me into the station.
GUILTY .

â€”He then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of a like offence at this COURT on March 21st, 1896, and seven other convictions we proved against him; lie had been sentenced to five years' and eight years' penal servitude for feloniously uttering counterfeit coin
.â€”Six Years' Penal Servitude.

100.
ANNIE LAWRENCE (30)
, unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

p.hi: The witnesses in the last case repeated their evidence.

div1.p: The Prisoner's statement before the Magistrate; "The parcel I had was given me by a woman; she went across the road to a fried fish shop. I sat on the step a minute, and this gentleman came up and said, 'What have you there? I said, 'What has that to do with you? He said, 'What
have you in your hand?' I said, 'My parse'; he said. 'What have you in it?' I said, 'Money.' They snatched it from my hand."

GUILTY .â€”She had been tried at this Court in 1887, with Greatorex, and acquitted.â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, JANUARY 9TH, 1899.
